title: Nigella Lawson fuels rumours of romance with novellist Ronan Bennett, once wrongly convicted of IRA murder of policeman
text:
Nigella Lawson fuels rumours of romance with novellist Ronan Bennett, once wrongly convicted of IRA murder of policeman The pair enjoyed dinner together in London on Thursday night Share Get   
Nigella Lawson has been pictured enjoying a night out with Irish novelist and screenwriter Ronan Bennett , who was once wrongly convicted of the 1974 IRA murder of a policeman. 
The TV chef, 57, was seen leaving a restaurant in Hackney, London on Thursday night alongside Bennett, who has penned an upcoming BBC drama series based on Guy Fawkes. 
While a source close to Lawson has said the pair are “just friends”, another insider hinted at romance, revealing: “I assumed they were a couple from their body language and the way they looked at each other.” Nigella was previously wed to art dealer Charles Saatchi (Photo: Getty Images) Bennett pictured at the Edinburgh Festival in 2004 (Photo: Rex Features) 
“The flirtatious body language was there, she was playing with her hair and they seemed quite touchy-feely,” the source added to The Sun on Sunday . 
Mirror Celeb has reached out to the pair’s reps for comment. 
Bennett has published a string of novels and non-fiction books, as well as screenwriting for a slew of TV shows including Channel 4’s Top Boy and BBC One’s Hidden. 
In 1974, at the age of 18, he was wrongly convicted of murdering a policeman in Northern Ireland and spent 18 months in prison before the Court of Appeal overturned the conviction. 
Inspector Bill Elliott was killed during a shoot-out while investigating a bank robbery. Nigella was all smiles on her night out (Photo: Getty Images) Read More 
Following his release from jail, Bennett moved to England, where he was arrested and charged with conspiring to cause explosions against “persons unknown”. 
He vehemently denied any such charge and was acquitted of any wrongdoing. 
In an essay for The Guardian in 2000, he wrote: "After release I came to England, only to be arrested by Special Branch and charged, with 'persons unknown', of conspiring to cause explosions. The case was variously dubbed the Persons Unknown trial or the Anarchists trial - we were all voluble if unsophisticated young enemies of the state, all states. 
“We also had absolutely nothing to do with any explosions. After several months in custody, this charge was dropped and a different conspiracy charge preferred. Opening the Crown's case at the Old Bailey a year later, the prosecutor said we had conspired 'to overthrow society'. The jury acquitted us on all counts.” Bennett was wrongly convicted for the murder of a policeman in 1974. The Court of Appeals overturned his conviction (Photo: Rex Features) Read More A slimmed down Nigella Lawson hits the shops make-up free as she runs errands for Christmas 
He said in the essay that his experience with the law had led to a lifelong interest in the criminal justice system. He went on to attain a PhD in the field and has campaigned against miscarriages of justice over the years. 
Bennett again made headlines in 1987 when Jeremy Corbyn appointed him parliamentary researcher, in a move deemed controversial at the time and raised questions about security clearance in the House of Commons, according to BBC. 
He most recently wrote the scripts for upcoming BBC drama series Gunpowder, starring Game of Thrones’ Kit Harrington. It tells the story of British activist Guy Fawkes and the plot to blow up the House of Lords in the 17th century. Like us on Facebook
